Sometimes it's cool to be in the classroom, reminded of why we teach what we teach, and see growth from students. Esp. when its a reminder of the "why" that led me to this profession. Academia is rough & morale is low rn. This blip of positivity was a welcome change of pace! https://t.co/PGqf1lc73Q

Student in grade K killed her lesson, after weeks of planning and preparation. Nothing beats that debrief meeting! (What's awesome is she entered as a student my 1st year on the faculty and I've taught her in a few classes over the years. Growth is so cool!) https://t.co/573CECo3rC

One K student tried get me to stay by trying to say that her class needed an extra teacher bc her teacher was so stressed, tired, and deserved the help. She said "COVID took all her energy. But I bet you and Ms. [Student] can help after lunch!" She teared up when we left. https://t.co/3NrICfFeje

In grade K it was clear that hugs are the thing that gets everyone through the day. In the 1 hr I was in their class I received ~15 unsolicited/unplanned hugs. They had perfected the "sneak-attack hug" where they bring it in from blind spots. I'm not a huge hugger but it was cute https://t.co/f4PABES1p9

Another 3rd grader looked at my notes & asked me "What language are you writing in? Where are you from?" I wrote in cursive, folks. He said he hadn't seen it before and explained he preferred to "write using the buttons on his keyboard." He suggested I try it -he said it was fun. https://t.co/MtVilqYNmv

One of the 3rd graders asked me why I was there and asked about college. He was convinced I brought a school bus to drive my student home or take them on a field trip. Then he went on to show me everything he did during the activities. He was articulate, curious & attn-deprived. https://t.co/klgzsXD6GK

The impact that their teaching has on the students is so powerful. Today I watched a lab about rocks/minerals w 3rd graders. Using inquiry learning they sorted the soil from rocks and categorized the rocks. The conversations heard were so cool. 😍 https://t.co/TLhCaOPAYy

Recently, I've spend time in a Kindergarden and 3rd grade classroom w 2 teacher candidates from my university. I'm so grateful to see their teaching and it's fun to see impact of training on their pedagogy. BC I taught HS b4 entering HE, so it's fun to interact w the kiddos. 🧵

Other tips from my experience: close your eyes as soon as you can, leading up to test. Don't want to see that nasal swab. Don't go when you're in a hurry. I got in line early and it took ~90 mins from the time they opened until I left. Breathe-I had a panick attack starting there

But I learned a tip for your test to be less uncomfortable: The individual who took my test told me to breath out of my mouth slowly, like I'm blowing out a candle when the swab was placed in my nasal cavity and when they removed it from the cavity. Eyes watered but not much pain

Advice for surviving here long term:
1) Keep your head down.
2) Do your job to the letter of the contract. Nothing more or less. Unless it's for a student. 
3) Keep your head down.
4) Retire as quickly as possible.
5) Fully stocked home bar. 
6) Finding safe people to vent to.

*=also assume nothing will happen bc of mtg
* *= There is likely an admin mole at the meeting keeping score and a list of anything negative said.  
***=Preferably at a bar with good food and using the word "fuck" a ton

Advice on not getting pissed about useless meetings:
1) Assume the mtg is happening to make you feel important OR to check a box.*
2) Don't speak @ mtg unless it's on script or you are tenured.**
3) Leave ASAP.
4) Once in a safe space vent to safe ppl.***
5) Forget mtg happened.

Advice for ending your day:
1) Shutdown your work in time to be out your door when your office hrs end.
2) Walk to your car as quickly possible.
3) Drive home quickly
4) Forget the uni exists
5) Pour yourself a double bourbon on the rocks. 
6) Repeat step 6 until you feel better.
